Subject: Question on competitive coevolution setup from paper
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=190115458; y=KfUwtOgvTnfI1n5MKsFXLryvaWEHjDbBVH3woOXzKwQKha6ROHadmx-Hv7BiWSs_Z9iKmNYrP0xnc3E
X-Yahoo-Profile: ze_dakster

Ken,

Stupid question here, I'm going through the "Competitive Coevolution
Through Evolutionary Complexification" paper, and I'm curious about
the doubling of the evaluations so that the host being evaluated
starts in both the east and west position against the same opponent.
Being that the board is symmetrical, and none of the neural inputs
indicate any form of "north", or absolute position, isn't this
unnecessary? It seems to me that the agents/robots wouldn't be able to
perceive any difference between the two starting points.

I'm probably missing something simple, but the idea of halving the
number of evaluations is attractive if there isn't much benefit to the
second evaluation.


-Drew
